{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12222,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mycena oregonensis is a type of mushroom that typically thrives in moist environments. Unlike typical houseplants, this species does not require direct watering. Instead, focus on maintaining a high humidity level in its environment. Ensure that the substrate it grows on remains moist but not soggy by misting it lightly whenever the surface begins to appear dry. Avoid pooling water, as excessive moisture can lead to rot and fungal diseases, which are detrimental to the health of the Mycena mushrooms."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mycena oregonensis typically thrives in low-light conditions, as it naturally grows in shaded, wooded environments on decaying wood. Direct sunlight can be harmful, causing the substrate to dry out and potentially damaging the delicate structure of the mushrooms. Instead, aim to replicate its natural habitat by providing a location with indirect light, such as near a north-facing window or in a room with diffused lighting. Constant low illumination levels mimic the dappled sunlight filtering through forest canopies where this species is often found."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning generally does not apply to Mycena oregonensis, as it is a type of fungus rather than a plant with traditional stems and leaves. However, if you notice any parts of the mushroom that are decaying or discolored, you can gently remove these sections to prevent the spread of any potential disease or mold. Always handle mushrooms delicately to avoid damaging their fragile structure during this process. Regular observation and removing unhealthy parts can help maintain the overall health of the fungal growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Western Yellow Mycena","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Western Yellow Mycena"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Mycena oregonensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13223,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lathyrus sulphureus, commonly known as the yellow pea, requires moderate watering. It's essential to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, as soggy conditions can lead to root rot. During the growing season, especially in dry periods, ensure that the plant receives adequate water. However, allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to avoid overwatering. In its dormant period, reduce the frequency, letting the soil dry out more thoroughly. Always use well-draining soil to maintain the right moisture balance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lathyrus sulphureus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with intense summers, a location that offers morning sun with some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat, which might stress or scorch it. Ensure that the planting site is free from shade cast by larger plants or structures. While this plant can tolerate partial sun, the number and vibrancy of its blooms are generally reduced without sufficient light exposure, impeding its full flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lathyrus sulphureus is necessary to encourage healthy growth and flowering. Begin by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased stems throughout the growing season to maintain plant health. After the plant flowers, deadhead spent blooms to potentially encourage a second bloom and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Regularly trimming back excessive growth can help maintain a tidy appearance and improve air circulation around the plant. Early spring is an ideal time for more substantial pruning, before new growth starts, to shape the plant and remove any overwintered damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sulphur pea","description":"Lathyrus sulphureus is a species of wild pea known by the common names snub pea and sulphur pea.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Sulphur pea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lathyrus sulphureus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13517,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Psathyrotes ramosissima, commonly known as turtleback or velvet rosette, is a drought-tolerant plant native to desert regions. When cultivating this plant, its watering needs are minimal due to its adaptation to arid environments. It thrives with infrequent watering, ensuring the soil is allowed to dry completely between waterings. Overwatering should be strictly avoided as it can lead to root rot and other health issues. A guideline is to water only during extended dry spells or during the hottest periods of its growing season. Ensure good drainage in the soil to further minimize water retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Psathyrotes ramosissima prefers full sun exposure, replicating its native environment in the deserts of the southwestern United States. It should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to thrive. The plant's adaptability to high sun and heat conditions makes it suitable for xeriscaping and gardens that simulate desert conditions. In suboptimal lighting, the plant may show stunted growth, leggy stems, or fewer flowers. Therefore, ensuring proper sunlight exposure is crucial for its development and overall health, aligning its growth with its natural sun-drenched habitats."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally not a major requirement for Psathyrotes ramosissima as it is a low-growing, mounded plant. However, light pruning can be beneficial to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. This can be done by trimming back any dead or damaged foliage, promoting air circulation within the plant and preventing disease. For optimal results, conduct pruning during its dormant season to avoid stressing the plant. Careful removal of spent flowers can also help enhance its appearance and divert energy towards producing new foliage and blooms."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Turtleback","description":"Psathyrotes ramosissima is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common name velvet turtleback, or turtleback. It is native to the southwestern United States where it grows in desert scrub habitat. It is a low, neatly mounded plant producing spreading stems which are hairless to densely woolly in texture. Leaves are borne on long petioles. The leaf blade is variable in shape, generally roughly rounded, and up to 2 centimeters long....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Turtleback"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Psathyrotes ramosissima"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Reduce watering significantly in the winter months when the plant is dormant. If planted in an area with less than optimal sunlight, expect longer stems and reduced flowering. Ensure that the plant receives ample sunlight to facilitate photosynthesis, which supports its rapid growth and flowering throughout its active seasons. A south-facing location is ideal if you're growing it in a garden or a pot outside."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Lupinus argenteus, or the silvery lupine, helps maintain plant health and appearance. Regularly deadhead the spent flowers throughout the blooming season to encourage continuous blooming. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13618,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senna marilandica, commonly known as wild senna, requires moderate watering. It thrives best in average, well-drained soil and does not tolerate prolonged periods of wet soil, which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, a weekly watering schedule is generally sufficient, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. It's important to reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant. In drought conditions, additional watering may be necessary to maintain plant health and ensure vibrant blooms."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senna marilandica thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate some light shade, but full sun conditions are preferred to produce the best floral displays. When planted in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ensure it is placed in an area with ample sunlight to mimic its natural prairie and open woodland habitats, promoting robust and healthy growth throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senna marilandica is relatively straightforward and is primarily done to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Early spring, just before new growth starts, is the ideal time for pruning. Remove any dead or damaged stems and cut back any overly long or unruly branches to promote a tidy shape. Deadheading, the removal of spent flowers, can encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from self-seeding if you wish to control its spread. Minimal pruning is required for this low-maintenance plant unless shaping is desired."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Maryland senna","description":"Senna marilandica, the Maryland senna or Maryland wild senna, is a flowering plant in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Maryland senna"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Senna marilandica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If grown indoors, placing the plant near a north or east-facing window can provide the right amount of light without the risk of exposure to harsh rays. If pruning, use sharp, sterile scissors to carefully remove any overgrown or damaged fronds to promote healthy growth. Prune away dead or diseased sections promptly to prevent any potential spread of disease. Always handle the plant gently during pruning, as the delicate structure of liverworts can be easily damaged. Proper pruning encourages denser growth and maintains the overall appearance of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flat-leaved Scalewort","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Flat-leaved Scalewort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Radula complanata"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13121,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Geranium pyrenaicum prefers moderate watering, requiring that the soil be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's important to let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the warm growing season, you may need to water more frequently, especially if planted in containers, while in cooler months, reduce watering frequency. Always ensure that the plant has adequate drainage to avoid standing water, as soggy conditions can be detrimental. Observe the plant for signs of drought stress, such as wilting leaves, and adjust watering accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Geranium pyrenaicum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, providing afternoon shade can prevent heat stress and plant wilting. Too little light can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms, so aim to place this plant in a bright spot. If located indoors, a south or west-facing window works well. Adjust the sunlight exposure seasonally, if necessary, to ensure the plant continues to receive adequate light throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geranium pyrenaicum helps maintain its shape and encourages healthier growth. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to promote continued blooming and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. In early spring, prune back any dead or damaged stems to stimulate new growth. In its natural habitat, this plant survives on rainfall alone, so mimicking those conditions by letting nature take its course during wetter months is ideal. It's essential to plant it in well-draining soil to prevent excess moisture retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Penstemon clevelandii thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. It is adapted to dry, arid environments and can withstand intense sunlight. When situating this plant in your garden, choose a location that provides abundant sunlight exposure. Insufficient sunlight can result in fewer blooms and a spindly growth habit. This species performs well in rock gardens, sunny slopes, and dry landscapes where it can receive uninterrupted sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Penstemon clevelandii helps maintain its shape and encourages new blooms. After the flowering period, typically in late spring to early summer, you can deadhead spent flowers to promote additional blooming. Cutting back the stems to a third of their length can help rejuvenate the plant and encourage a bushier growth habit. In late winter, just before new growth starts emerging, prune back any dead or damaged stems to prepare the plant for the upcoming growing season. Regular pruning also prevents the plant from becoming too leggy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cleveland's Beardtongue","description":"Penstemon clevelandii is a species of penstemon known by the common name Cleveland's beardtongue. This deadheading process helps maintain a tidy appearance and can produce a longer blooming period. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season to promote better air circulation and plant health. However, it's crucial to ensure that the water it's in remains clean and nutrient-rich, meaning regular water changes in contained environments like aquariums or ponds are necessary to prevent stagnation and promote healthy growth. On average, changing about 20-30% of the water weekly should suffice, depending on the plant's growth rate and the water quality."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lemna trisulca thrives in full to partial sunlight, as this plant's water-bound lifestyle allows it to absorb plentiful light. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of sunlight per day. However, it is tolerant of a variety of light conditions and can survive under indirect or dappled light. If grown indoors, placing it in a location where it receives sufficient natural light is beneficial. Too much direct sunlight might cause water to overheat or encourage algae growth, so balance is key to maintaining a healthy aquatic environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lemna trisulca involves managing its rapid growth to prevent it from dominating the water surface entirely. Regularly thin out excess plants to provide proper light penetration for any submerged plants and maintain good water quality. Use a fine mesh scoop or a skimmer to remove sections of the duckweed. This process not only helps in controlling its covering but also prevents decomposing plants from affecting water quality. Ensure to keep a balanced amount to support the ecosystem's needs or aesthetic preferences in your water garden or aquarium."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Ivy-leaved Duckweed","description":"Lemna trisulca L. (syn. Staurogeton trisulcus (L.) Schur; star duckweed; ivy-leaved duckweed) is a species of aquatic plants in the arum family Araceae. It has a subcosmopolitan distribution. Unlike other duckweeds, it has submerged rather than floating fronds, except when flowering or fruiting.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America","Asia"],"other_name":["Ivy-leaved Duckweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lemna trisulca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Wet"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

For the canes that bore fruit the previous year, prune them after fruiting as these will not bear fruit again. If some leaves turn brown or dry out, carefully pluck or snip them off with clean scissors to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent any potential spread of rot. If the plant has produced pups, you can also prune these, replant them, or allow them to grow for a fuller appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"ballmoss","description":"Tillandsia recurvata, commonly known as small ballmoss or ball moss, is a flowering plant (not a true moss) in the family Bromeliaceae that grows upon larger host plants. During the winter months, watering can be reduced, ensuring that the soil does not stay soggy. Always use room temperature water when irrigating to prevent shocking the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pellaea atropurpurea thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sunlight but should be protected from harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch the fronds. Ideally, it should be placed near an east or north-facing window where it can receive morning or filtered light. In lower light conditions, the plant may experience slow growth, so supplementing with artificial light can be beneficial. Ensuring the plant receives stable lighting conditions without drastic shifts helps maintain its vibrant foliage and growth rate."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pellaea atropurpurea is minimal and involves removing any dead or damaged fronds to encourage healthy growth. Using sterilized scissors or pruning shears, cut the fronds at the base where they meet the stem. Regularly removing debris and dead foliage not only improves its appearance but also helps prevent the spread of disease. It is also beneficial to occasionally thin out overcrowded fronds to improve air circulation around the plant. Inspecting the plant for signs of any pests or disease during pruning is also a good practice."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"purple-stem cliffbrake","description":"Pellaea atropurpurea, commonly known as purple-stem cliffbrake or just purple cliffbrake, is a fern native to North and Central America. It is crucial not to let water sit on the leaves or in the soil, as this can lead to fungal infections. During winter or dormant periods, reduce watering frequency further, just enough to keep the plant from completely drying out. Overwatering can be detrimental, so it's better to err on the side of too little water rather than too much."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The round-leaved geranium thrives best in areas with full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive about 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. Too much shade can result in weak, leggy growth and a reduced number of flowers. While it can tolerate some afternoon sun, in hotter climates, it might appreciate some light afternoon shade to protect it from intense sunlight, which can cause leaf burn. If grown indoors, place it near a bright, south or west-facing window to ensure it gets adequate light, supplementing with artificial grow lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for the healthy growth of Geranium rotundifolium. Remove any dead or damaged leaves regularly to promote air circulation and prevent disease. After the flowering season, cut back the old flower stalks and any leggy growth to encourage a more compact and bushy plant. Pruning should be done with clean, sharp shears to prevent any damage to the plant. If the plant becomes too large or unkempt, it can also benefit from a more substantial cut-back in late winter or early spring. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13226,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lepidium campestre, commonly known as field pepperweed, is a hardy plant that does not require frequent watering once established. It prefers well-drained, dry to medium moisture soil conditions. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In general, allow the soil to dry out between waterings, especially in cooler seasons. During prolonged dry spells, occasional deep watering may be beneficial, but the plant is drought-tolerant and typically handles periods of low moisture well. Ensuring that the soil has good drainage will facilitate healthy growth and prevent water-related issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Field pepperweed thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, though this may result in reduced flowering and a slightly leggier growth habit. In regions with extreme afternoon sun, some protection during the hottest part of the day can be beneficial to prevent potential leaf scorch. Overwatering is a common issue with this plant, so ensure that the pot has excellent drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Psilostrophe cooperi thrives in full sun and should be placed in a location where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so ensure it receives ample light to stay healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Psilostrophe cooperi is generally minimal and mainly done to maintain its shape and remove any dead or damaged stems. Prune after the blooming period to encourage new growth and sometimes a second bloom. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to cut back leggy or unruly branches, focusing on maintaining a compact shape. Removing spent flowers can also help to tidy up the plant and potentially stimulate additional blooms. Always avoid heavy pruning in late autumn or winter, as this can impact the plant's growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Whitestem Paperflower","description":"Psilostrophe cooperi is a flowering plant in the daisy family known by the common names Cooper's paper daisy and whitestem paperflower. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13020,"attracts":["Aquatic insects","Fish"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Elodea canadensis, commonly known as Canadian waterweed, thrives in aquatic environments where its roots can remain constantly submerged. Unlike terrestrial plants, Elodea does not require traditional watering methods. Instead, ensure the aquatic environment, such as an aquarium or pond, maintains clean water with a steady supply of nutrients. Regularly change part of the water to prevent stagnation and reduce the buildup of harmful toxins. The plant absorbs nutrients from the water, so providing an enriched aquatic fertilizer occasionally can support its growth. Avoid hard or chlorinated water, as it can damage the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Elodea canadensis requires moderate to high lighting conditions to photosynthesize effectively. In natural ponds, this plant benefits from indirect sunlight. When kept in aquariums, aim for artificial lighting that simulates natural sunlight, such as full-spectrum fluorescent lights, providing around 8-12 hours of light per day. Insufficient lighting can cause the plant to grow poorly, leading to weaker and elongated stems. Conversely, too much light can promote excessive algae growth, which competes with Elodea for nutrients. Adjust the distance of the light source to prevent overheating and ensure it reaches all parts of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Elodea canadensis involves trimming its stems to control growth and prevent over-crowding in the aquatic environment. Use a pair of sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut the stems back, ideally just above the leaf junctions. This encourages bushier growth and prevents the plant from taking over the tank or pond. Regular pruning, depending on the growth rate, which is often vigorous, will keep Elodea healthy and manageable. Remove any decaying or dead sections to prevent detritus from accumulating in the water. Pruning also helps maintain a balanced ecosystem for other aquatic life."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Canadian Waterweed","description":"Elodea canadensis (American or Canadian waterweed or pondweed) is a perennial aquatic plant, or submergent macrophyte, native to most of North America. It has been introduced widely to regions outside its native range and was first recorded from the British Isles in about 1836.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Canadian Waterweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Algae"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Elodea canadensis"],"soil":["Aquatic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13820,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dactylorhiza maculata, or the spotted orchid, prefers consistently moist conditions, as excessive dryness can stress the plant or cause its demise. Water it regularly, ensuring the soil remains evenly moist, mimicking its natural habitat—typically damp meadows or wetlands. However, avoid waterlogging, as overly soggy conditions can suffocate the roots and lead to rot. In periods of dry weather, increase watering frequency. Additionally, a layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture, but it is essential to ensure it does not completely cover the base to avoid moisture buildup and root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The spotted orchid thrives best in partial to dappled sunlight, mimicking the light conditions found under the canopy in its native habitats. It can tolerate full sun if provided with sufficient moisture and protection during the hottest part of the day, but it generally prefers a spot with morning sun and afternoon shade. Too much direct, intense sunlight can scorch the leaves, so it's important to find a balance that provides indirect light whilst avoiding prolonged exposure to harsh midday sun. During indoor cultivation, place it near a bright window but out of direct sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dactylorhiza maculata involves minimal maintenance beyond removing spent flower spikes and any dead or damaged foliage to tidy up the plant and maintain its health. Cut back the flower spikes after bloom fades, which encourages the plant to focus energy on root and foliage development. Ensure that pruning shears are sterilized to prevent disease transmission. Moreover, in colder climates, remove any withered plant material in late autumn, allowing for new growth in spring. This practice will also help minimize the risk of fungal infections and pests harboring in dead plant matter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"heath spotted orchid","description":"Dactylorhiza maculata, known as the heath spotted-orchid or moorland spotted orchid, is an herbaceous perennial plant belonging to the family Orchidaceae. It is also found in Algeria, Morocco, and western Siberia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["heath spotted orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Anthracnose","Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Dactylorhiza maculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Wet","Boggy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13227,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lepidium densiflorum, commonly known as common peppergrass, is generally drought-tolerant and does not require frequent watering. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, especially in heavier soils. It's best to water this plant sparingly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out before watering again. In dry climates or during prolonged periods of heat, it may require more regular watering. Always ensure that the plant has good drainage to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lepidium densiflorum prefers full sun to thrive. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. The plant can tolerate partial shade, but too little light may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. It is well-suited to sunny, open areas such as meadows, road sides, and garden beds. If growing indoors or in areas with limited natural light, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to ensure the plant receives enough light to maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lepidium densiflorum is typically minimal since it is a naturally low-growing, self-seeding annual. However, to maintain a tidy appearance and prevent it from spreading aggressively, you can deadhead spent flowers to reduce seed production. Pruning can also help encourage a bushier growth habit. In late fall or early spring, you might consider cutting back any dried or dead stems to make way for new, vigorous growth in the growing season. Always use sharp, clean tools to avoid damage and disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Peppergrass","description":"Lepidium densiflorum is a species of flowering plant in the mustard family known by the common names common pepperweed and prairie peppergrass.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Common Peppergrass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lepidium densiflorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12226,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Suillus caerulescens is a mycorrhizal fungus that typically grows in symbiosis with pine trees. While it naturally seeks moisture, it usually does not require direct watering when found in its wild habitat. If you are cultivating this fungus indoors or in a controlled environment, ensure that the substrate or soil remains moist but not waterlogged. It is crucial to maintain high humidity levels to mimic its natural forest floor environment. Regular misting or using humidity trays can help achieve the appropriate environment. Always allow for adequate drainage to avoid any fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Suillus caerulescens naturally grows in shady, forested environments usually under pine trees, which means it prefers indirect sunlight. If cultivating this mushroom, aim to replicate this environment by providing filtered or dappled light conditions. Direct sunlight may dry out the substrate, which is not ideal for its growth. Consider setting up your cultivation space with indirect lighting or placing it in a naturally shaded area. Ensuring a balance of light and shade will help in simulating the natural conditions this fungus thrives in."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Suillus caerulescens, being a type of bolete mushroom, does not require pruning. However, if you are managing a mushroom cultivation area or a garden where this mushroom is present, you might want to ensure that there is regular removal of old or decaying fungi from the area. This not only helps in maintaining the health of the environment but also prevents any potential spread of fungi-related decay or disease. Routine observation and clean-up will aid in maintaining the aesthetics and health of the cultivation site."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fat Jack","description":"Suillus caerulescens is a species of bolete fungus in the family Suillaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13323,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Menyanthes trifoliata, commonly known as bogbean, thrives in moist environments and often grows semi-submerged in shallow water. To care for this plant, ensure that the soil is consistently moist and do not allow it to dry out. In aquatic or bog garden settings, it can even withstand being submerged in several inches of water, provided the water is not stagnant. Regular monitoring to maintain the appropriate moisture levels is essential, especially during dry spells or hot weather, to mimic its natural habitat and promote healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Menyanthes trifoliata prefers full sun to partial shade for optimum growth. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily, which helps in producing more vibrant flowers and healthy foliage. However, it can also tolerate partial shade conditions, making it versatile in natural settings. When planted in shaded areas, the flowering may reduce, but the plant can still thrive if other growth conditions such as soil moisture and nutrient availability are met. Position the plant accordingly to match its sunlight needs and local climate."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Menyanthes trifoliata involves removing dead or damaged leaves and spent flower stems to maintain the plant's health and appearance. This task can be performed in late spring to early summer, following the flowering period, or as needed throughout the growing season. Pruning helps prevent the spread of disease by removing decaying plant material and encourages more robust growth by focusing the plant's energy on healthy parts. Using clean, sharp scissors or garden shears will minimize damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bogbean","description":"Menyanthes is a monotypic genus of flowering plants in the family Menyanthaceae containing the single species Menyanthes trifoliata. The name Menyanthes comes from the Greek words menyein, meaning \"disclosing\", and anthos, meaning \"flower\", in reference to the sequential opening of flowers on the inflorescence. The North American form is often referred to as M. trifoliata var. minor Michx. It is known in English by the common names bogbean and buckbean.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Bogbean"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Menyanthes trifoliata"],"soil":["Acidic","Moist","Peaty","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13621,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sesbania punicea, also known as the Rattlebox or Scarlet Wisteria, thrives best in moist environments but is quite tolerant to occasional dry spells. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist during its growing season in spring and summer. Water the plant deeply until the water drains from the bottom of the pot, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. During the dormant winter months, reduce the watering frequency as the plant requires less moisture to maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sesbania punicea thrives in full sun, where it can receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This exposure is critical for robust flowering and healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight can lead to fewer blooms and a less vigorous appearance. In areas with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade may prevent leaf scorch and ensure a longer blooming period. Adequate sunlight also helps in maintaining the plant's shape and encourages dense, compact foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sesbania punicea is essential to maintain its shape and prevent it from becoming leggy, especially in garden settings. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Additionally, thinning the canopy can help in controlling its spread and promoting a more bushy growth. Regular pruning also encourages the plant to produce more flowers. It is advisable to wear gloves as the plant might be irritating to sensitive skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scarlet Sesbane","description":"Sesbania punicea (Spanish gold, rattlebox, or scarlet sesban) is an ornamental shrub that produces reddish-orange flowers, has deciduous leaves, and grows to 15 feet high. This plant has a high demand for water, and thrives in swamps or high-moisture areas. It also requires a mildly acidic soil to grow, ranging between 6.1 and 6.5 pH.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Scarlet Sesbane"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Sesbania punicea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12924,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Coreopsis tinctoria, commonly known as Plains Coreopsis, prefers moderate watering practices. This plant thrives in soil that is kept evenly moist but not consistently soggy. During the growing season, it is best to water when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. Be cautious about overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. In the dormant season, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing the soil to dry out more between waterings. Since it can tolerate drought conditions, aim to maintain a balance, providing enough moisture for healthy growth without excess."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coreopsis tinctoria flourishes in full sun, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This exposure helps the plant produce vibrant blooms and grow robustly. Though it can tolerate partial shade, growth and flower production may not be as vigorous. Ensure the planting location receives ample light to prevent the plant from becoming leggy and underdeveloped. If growing in a hot climate, some afternoon shade can help reduce stress from peak heat. The more sunlight they receive, the better they will perform, making full sun areas ideal for this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coreopsis tinctoria is essential for promoting longer bloom periods and maintaining the plant's shape. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, is crucial. This will encourage the plant to produce more blooms throughout the growing season. It is best to snip off the flowers just above the next set of leaves. In late fall, after the plant has finished flowering, cut back the stems to about 1-2 inches above the soil to help rejuvenate the plant for the next season. This also helps in controlling self-seeding if desired, as it reduces the spread of seeds."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"plains coreopsis","description":"Plains coreopsis, garden tickseed, golden tickseed, or calliopsis, Coreopsis tinctoria, is an annual forb. The plant is common to Canada (from Quebec to British Columbia), northeast Mexico (Coahuila, Nuevo León, Tamaulipas), and much of the United States, especially the Great Plains and Southern states where it is often called \"calliopsis.\" The species is also widely cultivated in and naturalized in China.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["plains coreopsis"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leafhoppers"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Coreopsis tinctoria"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12723,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asclepias curassavica, commonly known as tropical milkweed, prefers well-drained soil and requires regular watering, especially during its growing season. Water deeply but allow the topsoil to dry out between sessions to avoid waterlogging and root rot. During the warmer months, increase the frequency of watering, but be cautious not to overwater as this plant is somewhat drought-tolerant. In cooler months, reduce watering, ensuring the soil remains just slightly moist. It’s important to avoid letting the plant sit in stagnant water, so ensure proper drainage in its pot or garden location."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asclepias curassavica thrives best in full sun exposure for at least 6 to 8 hours a day. Providing ample sunlight ensures robust growth and plentiful blooming. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in the hottest parts of the day, insufficient sunlight can result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. If grown indoors or in a shaded garden area, consider supplementing with grow lights to achieve optimal conditions. It's a sun-loving plant that performs best in open, bright locations, replicating conditions similar to its native tropical environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asclepias curassavica involves trimming to encourage bushier growth and to remove any dead or diseased stems. It’s best to prune in early spring as the plant comes out of dormancy. Cut back the stems to about 6 inches to promote fresh growth. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also encourage further blooming throughout the season. Regularly inspect for any damaged or insect-infested parts and remove them promptly. At the end of the growing season, a more significant cutback can help prepare the plant for the next growth cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tropical milkweed","description":"Asclepias curassavica, commonly known as tropical milkweed, is a flowering plant species of the milkweed genus, Asclepias. It is native to the American tropics and has a pantropical distribution as an introduced species. Other common names include bloodflower or blood flower, cotton bush, hierba de la cucaracha, Mexican butterfly weed, redhead, scarlet milkweed, and wild ipecacuanha.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red, Orange, Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["tropical milkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Asclepias curassavica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12326,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Eriogonum luteolum, commonly known as yellow buckwheat, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in dry, arid conditions. It requires minimal watering once established. During its initial growth period, provide moderate watering to help the roots establish. Once established, water only during extended periods of drought or extremely dry conditions. Over-watering can lead to root rot and fungal diseases, so it's best to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Ensure good drainage in the soil to prevent standing water around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eriogonum luteolum thrives in full sunlight and will perform best in locations with at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. It is well-suited for dry, open landscapes where it can enjoy the unfiltered sun. If planted in a shadier spot, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ideally, choose a spot with southern or southwestern exposure to ensure ample light, which will promote vigorous flowering and maintain the compact form typical of this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Eriogonum luteolum involves removing spent flower heads and any dead or damaged branches. This should be done in the late fall or early winter after the flowering season. Deadheading the flowers can promote a longer bloom period. It is also helpful to cut back any leggy growth to encourage a compact shape. Avoid heavy pruning, as the plant does not respond well to drastic cuts. Regular light pruning will help maintain healthy growth without over-stressing the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wicker buckwheat","description":"Eriogonum luteolum is a species of wild buckwheat known by the common name goldencarpet buckwheat. It is native to many of the mountain ranges of California and southern Oregon, including the Sierra Nevada, Cascades and California Coast Ranges. It grows in mountain and foothill habitat, such as forest and woodland, on granite and sometimes serpentine soils.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Oregon"],"other_name":["wicker buckwheat"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Eriogonum luteolum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12524,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sagittaria graminea, commonly known as grass-leaved arrowhead, thrives in wet and marshy environments. It prefers consistently moist to wet soil and does best with regular watering to mimic its natural habitat. Ensure the soil remains wet but not waterlogged; standing water of a shallow depth is ideal. This plant can even tolerate being submerged in water, making it perfect for ponds or water garden edges. Adjust watering frequency according to the season, ensuring that during dry periods, it stays adequately hydrated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sagittaria graminea prefers full sunlight to partial shade for optimal growth. It thrives best in locations where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent excessive heat stress. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may affect its blooming and foliage density. For indoor or container cultivation, placing the plant near a bright, south-facing window will simulate these conditions effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sagittaria graminea involves removing dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth and improve appearance. Be cautious not to over-prune as it can stress the plant; a conservative approach, trimming just the tips, can yield the best results."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"black crowberry","description":"Empetrum nigrum, crowberry, black crowberry, or, in western Alaska, blackberry, is a flowering plant species in the heather family Ericaceae with a near circumboreal distribution in the northern hemisphere. During the growing season, from spring to early fall, water the plant deeply once a week, more frequently in hot or dry periods, ensuring the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering in winter when the plant is dormant. It’s important to let the top inch of soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Adjust your watering schedule based on rainfall and temperature variations."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acer palmatum thrives in partial shade to full sun; however, it generally prefers a location with dappled sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade. Be mindful of the specific variety's light needs, as some tolerate full sun better than others. Ensure the planting location avoids extremes of sun or shade to promote balanced growth and vibrant foliage throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acer palmatum is typically done in late winter or early spring while the tree is still dormant. This helps stimulate new growth during the spring. Remove dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. Thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid heavy pruning, as Japanese Maples do best with minor shaping and thinning; drastic cuts can stress the tree. Always use sharp, clean pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease. Light maintenance can also be done throughout the growing season to remove any unwanted growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese maple","description":"Acer palmatum, commonly known as palmate maple, Japanese maple or smooth Japanese-maple (Japanese: irohamomiji, イロハモミジ, or momiji, 紅葉), is a species of woody plant native to Japan, China, Korea, eastern Mongolia, and southeast Russia. Observing the soil to maintain it slightly damp but not waterlogged is key."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Orthotrichum lyellii thrives in shaded or semi-shaded environments, as it naturally grows in forest understories. For outdoor growth, positioning it under a tree canopy or a structure that provides dappled shade is ideal. Maintaining a balance of low light with adequate humidity will encourage the healthiest growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Orthotrichum lyellii is minimal, as it's a moss and doesn't grow like typical garden plants with stems and leaves that require regular pruning. However, removing any dead or discolored portions can promote healthy growth. Regular cleaning of debris on and around the plant will also help keep it healthy and allow it to absorb nutrients efficiently."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lyell's Bristle-moss","description":"Orthotrichum lyellii, also known as Lyell's bristle moss, is a species of acrocarpous moss belonging to the family Orthotrichaceae. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist but avoid stagnant conditions if potted. If grown in a pond, make sure the water level remains fairly high to cover the roots. If planted in a container, let the water level stay about an inch or two above the soil line, but ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. Weekly checks to maintain adequate water levels and conditions are recommended."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nelumbo nucifera thrives in full sunlight conditions. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote vigorous growth and abundant flowering. If grown in a greenhouse or indoors, positioning near south-facing windows or under grow lights that mimic full spectrum sunlight will be beneficial. Ensure that shading is minimal as inadequate light could result in poor flowering and weaker plants. Proper sunlight exposure is crucial to ensure the storied blooms of this revered aquatic plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning a lotus plant involves removing dead and yellowing leaves and spent flowers to encourage vibrant growth and prevent the spread of disease. This should be done by cutting the affected areas below the water level to avoid leaving unbecoming stalks which can decay in the water. During the dormant season, after the foliage naturally dies back, cut away any remaining stems to about an inch above the tuber. Regular inspection and maintenance help in keeping the plant healthy and flourishing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sacred Lotus","description":"Nelumbo nucifera, also known as Indian lotus, sacred lotus, or simply lotus, is one of two extant species of aquatic plant in the family Nelumbonaceae. For optimal growth, ensure that its roots are submerged in water or that the soil is consistently moist but not overly saturated to the point of stagnation. It can tolerate varying water depths, so a few inches of standing water is acceptable. During dry spells or if planted in containers, be diligent with watering to replicate its natural aquifer environment, ensuring the plant does not dry out. Over-watering is rarely a concern provided drainage is adequate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sagittaria sagittifolia prefers full to partial sunlight to thrive. Ideally, aim to provide around 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. If planted in shallow ponds or water gardens, full sun exposure promotes vigorous growth and flowering. However, in particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. The plant is quite adaptable and can tolerate some shade, but this may result in less prolific blooming. Ensure it receives adequate sunlight, especially during peak growing seasons, to maximize its lush foliage and bloom potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Sagittaria sagittifolia involves regular maintenance to encourage healthy growth and flowering. Trim away any dead or yellowing leaves near the base, especially during late spring and summer, to provide better air circulation and prevent disease. It's beneficial to remove spent flower stalks after blooming to discourage energy use on seed production, allowing the plant to focus on growth. Since this plant can spread via underground rhizomes, thinning clumps occasionally helps manage its size and prevents overcrowding. Pruning in early spring also prepares the plant for the upcoming growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arrowhead","description":"Sagittaria sagittifolia (also called arrowhead due to the shape of its leaves) is a flowering plant in the family Alismataceae, native to wetlands most of Europe from Ireland and Portugal to Finland and Bulgaria, and in Russia, Ukraine, Siberia, Japan, Turkey, China, Australia, Vietnam and the Caucasus. It is also cultivated as a food crop in some other countries. In Britain it is the only native Sagittaria.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Arrowhead"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spots","Rust fungi"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Rhizome Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Sagittaria sagittifolia"],"soil":["Wet","Marshy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

After establishment, watering should be infrequent; typically, natural rainfall will suffice. In particularly dry spells or extreme drought, provide supplemental watering, but ensure the soil dries out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. Overwatering should be avoided as it can harm the plant's health. It can tolerate partial sun, but this may result in sparser flowering and slower growth. In its native desert habitat, it copes well with the intense light levels, so indoors or in less sunny areas, choose the brightest spot available. Adequate sunlight ensures robust health and optimal floral display for the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Psorothamnus schottii is generally minimal, as the plant maintains a natural, bushy shape. However, occasional pruning can help remove any dead, damaged, or overgrown branches to improve airflow and maintain a neat appearance. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, and avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant. Pruning is mainly for aesthetic maintenance and health improvement."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Schott's Indigobush","description":"Psorothamnus schottii is a species of flowering plant in the legume family known by the common name Schott's dalea. During the growing season, it's best to water the plant deeply, but allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In general, once a week should be sufficient, but adjust based on local weather conditions and soil drainage. Reduce watering during the cooler months or when the plant is dormant, as excess moisture can harm its growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lepidium virginicum thrives best in full sun but can tolerate partial shade. While it can survive in shady conditions, reduced sunlight may result in less vigorous growth and fewer flowers. Adjust placement as needed to provide the necessary light for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lepidium virginicum is minimal, as the plant naturally grows into its typical shape without much intervention. However, to encourage bushier growth and to control its spread, you can lightly prune or pinch back the tips of the stems during the active growing season. Additionally, removing dead or damaged stems will help maintain the plant's health and vigor. The plant thrives in well-draining soil, so good drainage is crucial to maintain optimal moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Glehnia littoralis thrives best in full sun conditions but can tolerate partial shade. Ensure that the plant's location offers sufficient sunlight exposure to facilitate robust growth and flowering. Adjust planting spots accordingly if insufficient light leads to leggy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Glehnia littoralis is generally minimal, as it is an herbaceous perennial that maintains a manageable size and form. However, to encourage healthy growth and a neat appearance, remove any dead or yellowing leaves as they appear. At the end of the growing season, you can cut back the spent stems to promote robust regrowth in the following year. Avoid heavy pruning as excessive cutting may stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Beach Glehnia","description":"Glehnia is a genus in the carrot family, Apiaceae, with one species, Glehnia littoralis, known by several common names including beach silvertop and American silvertop in English, and bei sha shen (Chinese: 北沙參) and shan hu cai (Chinese: 珊瑚菜) in Chinese. The genus was named after Russian botanist Peter von Glehn.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Russia","China","Korea","Japan"],"other_name":["Beach Glehnia"],"pest_susceptibility":["No significant pest issues"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Glehnia littoralis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12728,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Asplenium septentrionale, commonly known as the forked spleenwort, prefers moist but well-draining soil conditions. This plant is adapted to rocky and sometimes arid environments, and thus, does not require frequent watering. It is best to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings, avoiding waterlogging which could lead to root rot. In general, watering once every week or two during the growing season should suffice, adjusting frequency based on humidity and temperature conditions. In winter, reduce watering further as the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Asplenium septentrionale thrives in partial shade to full shade conditions. It favors indirect sunlight and can even do well in low-light environments, making it suitable for areas with limited natural light. Direct sunlight may scorch its delicate fronds, so it’s best placed in an area that receives dappled sunlight or filtered light throughout the day. If indoors, situate the plant near a north or east-facing window, avoiding harsh afternoon sun. Adjust lighting conditions if the fronds start to show signs of stress or color change."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Asplenium septentrionale is minimal and mainly involves the removal of dead or damaged fronds to maintain the plant's appearance and health. This can be done throughout the growing season as needed. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruners to avoid damaging the plant, and cut fronds as close to the base as possible. Regular grooming ensures good air circulation around the plant and helps prevent any fungal infections. No major pruning is necessary as the plant retains a tidy form naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"northern spleenwort","description":"Asplenium septentrionale is a species of fern known by the common names northern spleenwort and forked spleenwort. It is native to western North America, Europe, and Asia, where it grows on rocks. Its long, slender leaves give it a distinctive appearance, more like a grass than a typical fern. Three subspecies exist, corresponding to a tetraploid and a diploid cytotype and their triploid hybrid.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["northern spleenwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Asplenium septentrionale"],"soil":["Rocky","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dry spells, make sure the soil or container in which it is planted remains consistently wet. In colder months, water levels should be maintained carefully to prevent the rhizomes from freezing, especially in non-tropical regions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nelumbo lutea thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to prosper. This plant is well-suited for outdoor ponds, water gardens, or large containers in locations that receive ample sun exposure. Insufficient sunlight may result in fewer blooms and leggy growth. This can typically be done in late fall or early spring before the plant enters a new growing season. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off the foliage at the base. Regularly removing dying or dead leaves throughout the growing season helps prevent disease. It's also beneficial to thin out any excess growth to maintain a balanced plant structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American lotus","description":"Nelumbo lutea is a species of flowering plant in the family Nelumbonaceae. If possible, choose a location with afternoon shade in extremely hot, dry climates to prevent stress on the plant. Adequate sunlight exposure will support its vibrant floral displays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Penstemon spectabilis involves removing spent flowers to encourage further blooming and promote a tidy appearance. After the main flowering phase, you can cut back the flowering stems to a set of leaves to stimulate new growth. Regularly remove any dead or diseased foliage to maintain plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Showy Penstemon","description":"Penstemon spectabilis is a species of penstemon known by the common name showy penstemon. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13924,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Ribes missouriense, or Missouri Gooseberry, prefers moderate watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, but young plants require regular watering to develop a strong root system. Water the plant deeply but infrequently allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Use mulching to help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. During dry spells or particularly hot weather, increase watering frequency, taking care to avoid waterlogging, which can damage the roots. Well-draining soil is important to prevent standing water, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ribes missouriense thrives in areas that receive full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should get at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from excessive heat stress. Adequate sunlight is essential for optimal growth and fruit production, as too little light can result in poor development and yield. When choosing a location for planting, ensure it is not overly shaded by larger trees or structures to allow the gooseberry plant enough light exposure throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning the Ribes missouriense is largely a matter of controlling its shape and encouraging healthy growth. Adequate sunlight ensures vibrant foliage coloration and robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cotyledon orbiculata involves removing dead or diseased leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth. It's best to prune the plant during its growing season in spring. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make cuts at the base of the leaf or stem. Avoid cutting healthy parts of the plant unless shaping is desired. Allow any cuts to callous over to prevent infection. Pruning not only helps maintain the plant's appearance but also promotes new growth and prevents pests and diseases from spreading through dead or decaying parts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"pig's ear","description":"Cotyledon orbiculata, commonly known as pig's ear or round-leafed navel-wort, is a South African succulent plant belonging to the Cotyledon genus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["pig's ear"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cotyledon orbiculata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This plant tolerates a range of water conditions but should not be allowed to dry out. If planted in a container or less naturally wet area, frequent watering may be necessary to maintain soil moisture, especially during dry spells or hot weather. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13826,"attracts":["Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echinocereus triglochidiatus, commonly known as claret cup cactus, requires careful watering to prevent root rot. Watering should be infrequent, allowing the soil to dry completely between waterings, especially in its growing season from spring to early summer. During winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant then enters dormancy and is more prone to rot with excess moisture. When watering, ensure that water drains thoroughly to prevent standing water around the roots. The plant thrives in well-draining, gritty soil that emulates its native arid environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echinocereus triglochidiatus thrives in full sun. It requires a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its optimal health and encourage blooming. Placing it in a sunny, south-facing window indoors or in an open area outside allows it to receive adequate light. Insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and a lack of flowers. However, when moving a plant from a shadier location to full sun, acclimatize it gradually to prevent sunburn on the cactus pads."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Echinocereus triglochidiatus is minimal, as it naturally maintains a compact shape. However, if necessary, prune in the spring to remove any damaged or diseased pads. Use clean, sharp tools to avoid diseases, and always wear gloves to protect yourself from the spines. If the plant becomes leggy or uneven, you can remove sections for propagation. After pruning, allow the cuts to callous over before watering to prevent fungal infections."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Kingcup Cactus","description":"Echinocereus triglochidiatus is a species of hedgehog cactus known by several common names, including kingcup cactus, claretcup, and Mojave mound cactus. This cactus is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it is a resident of varied habitats from low desert to rocky slopes, scrub, and mountain woodland. It is most abundant in shady areas.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Kingcup Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Cactus longhorn beetle"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Echinocereus triglochidiatus"],"soil":["Rocky","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13726,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Turritis glabra, commonly known as Tower Mustard, is a hardy plant that requires minimal watering. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to ensure the roots do not become waterlogged. Always use well-draining soil to prevent water stagnation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aristolochia clematitis thrives in partial to full sunlight. In shadier locations, the plant may become leggy as it stretches towards the light, so aim for a balance to maintain its compact form. It generally adapts well to varied light conditions, making it a versatile addition to different garden settings."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aristolochia clematitis is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation within the plant. Additionally, trimming back overgrown areas can help keep its size in check, especially if it is planted in a restricted space. Regularly remove any suckers or unwanted shoots that may appear at the base or along the stems.
